name: Real Estate
shortDescription: Become a licensed real estate agent or broker
description: A real estate license opens the door to one of the most flexible, high-earning careers available ‚Äî no degree required. Most states require 60-180 hours of pre-licensing education, passing a state exam, and finding a sponsoring broker. Top agents earn six figures within a few years.
requirements: Complete continuing education to maintain license

faqs.question: How long does it take to get a real estate license?
faqs.answer: Most people complete their pre-licensing education in 2-4 months and pass the exam within a few weeks after. You could be licensed in as little as 2 months depending on your state.

faqs.question: How much does it cost to get licensed?
faqs.answer: Total costs typically range from $500-$1,500, including coursework ($200-$700), exam fees ($50-$100), license application ($100-$300), and background check ($50-$100).

faqs.question: Do I need a college degree?
faqs.answer: No. Most states only require that you be 18-19 years old and have a high school diploma or GED. No college degree is needed.

faqs.question: Can I take the courses online?
faqs.answer: Yes! Most states approve online pre-licensing courses. This is the most popular option for flexibility and affordability.

name: Mortgage Loan Officer (MLO)
shortDescription: Help people finance their homes as a licensed MLO
description: Mortgage Loan Officers (MLOs) help borrowers navigate the home financing process. The SAFE Act requires all MLOs to complete 20 hours of NMLS-approved pre-licensing education, pass the SAFE MLO exam, and register through the NMLS. Many states have additional requirements. MLOs can earn excellent income through commissions.
requirements: Complete 20 hours of NMLS-approved pre-licensing education
Pass the SAFE MLO National Exam
Submit to background check and credit report

faqs.question: What is the NMLS?
faqs.answer: The Nationwide Multistate Licensing System (NMLS) is the system through which all mortgage loan originators are registered and licensed. You'll create an NMLS account as part of your licensing process.

faqs.question: Is the MLO exam hard?
faqs.answer: The SAFE MLO exam has a pass rate of about 55-60% on the first attempt. With proper preparation through a quality course, most people pass within 1-2 attempts.

faqs.question: How much can MLOs earn?
faqs.answer: Entry-level MLOs typically earn $45,000-$65,000. Experienced MLOs with a strong pipeline can earn $100,000-$200,000+ annually through commissions.

faqs.question: Do I need a degree?
faqs.answer: No degree is required. You need to be at least 18, complete the required education, pass the exam, and clear a background/credit check.

name: Appraisal
shortDescription: Value properties as a licensed appraiser
description: Real estate appraisers determine the market value of properties for purchases, refinances, and other transactions. The path starts as a Trainee Appraiser, progressing to Licensed, Certified Residential, and Certified General levels. It's a stable career with growing demand.
requirements: Complete required qualifying education hours (75+ hours for trainee)

faqs.question: How do I become an appraiser?
faqs.answer: Start by completing 75 hours of qualifying education, then find a supervising appraiser to work under while gaining experience. You can work as a trainee while building toward higher credentials.

faqs.question: What are the different appraiser levels?
faqs.answer: There are four levels: Trainee (75 hours education), Licensed Residential (150 hours + 1,000 experience hours), Certified Residential (200 hours + 1,500 experience hours), and Certified General (300 hours + 3,000 experience hours).

faqs.question: Is there demand for appraisers?
faqs.answer: Yes! The appraisal industry faces a significant shortage of new appraisers. Many current appraisers are nearing retirement, creating excellent opportunities for newcomers.

faqs.question: Can I do this part-time?
faqs.answer: Yes. Many trainee appraisers start part-time while working another job or completing their education. The flexibility increases as you gain experience.

name: Insurance
shortDescription: Sell insurance policies as a licensed agent
description: Insurance agents sell life, health, property, and casualty insurance policies. Each line of insurance requires its own license in most states. The barrier to entry is low ‚Äî complete a pre-licensing course and pass a state exam. Top agents build significant recurring income through renewals.
requirements: Complete state pre-licensing education (20-40 hours per line)

faqs.question: What types of insurance licenses are there?
faqs.answer: The main types are Life, Health, Property, and Casualty. Many agents get a Property & Casualty (P&C) combined license or a Life & Health combined license. You can hold multiple licenses.

faqs.question: How quickly can I start earning?
faqs.answer: Many agents start earning within their first month of being licensed. Commission-based roles mean your income scales with your effort and client base.

faqs.question: Is insurance a good career?
faqs.answer: Insurance offers strong income potential, flexibility, and job security. Renewals create recurring income, and top agents can build their own agencies.

faqs.question: Do I need a degree?
faqs.answer: No. Most states require only a high school diploma, pre-licensing education, and passing the state exam.

name: Home Inspection
description: Home inspectors evaluate the condition of residential properties before purchase. Most states require training, field experience, and passing an exam (often the National Home Inspector Exam). It's a hands-on career with independence and strong earning potential.
requirements: Complete state-approved training (60-200 hours depending on state)
Pass the National Home Inspector Exam (NHIE) or state exam

faqs.question: What does a home inspector do?
faqs.answer: Home inspectors evaluate the major systems of a home ‚Äî roof, foundation, plumbing, electrical, HVAC, and more ‚Äî and provide a detailed report to the buyer about the property's condition.

faqs.question: Can I be my own boss?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Most home inspectors are self-employed or run small businesses. You set your own schedule and rates. Many inspectors work 3-5 days a week and earn a great living.

faqs.question: What is the NHIE?
faqs.answer: The National Home Inspector Exam is used by most states as the licensing exam. It's a 200-question multiple choice test covering all aspects of home inspection.

faqs.question: How much can I charge per inspection?
faqs.answer: Most inspectors charge $300-$500 per inspection, with additional fees for larger homes or add-on services like radon testing. Full-time inspectors doing 3-4 inspections per week earn $50,000-$90,000+.
